section.title: What is new &productname; 16?
section.para: This article provides an overview of the key differences between &sls; 15 and 16.

listitem.para: &slsa; 15 supports &x86-64; (x86-64), &ibm; &power; LE (&ppc64le;), &zseries; (s390x), and ARM64 (aarch64). The required minimum architecture level for x86-64 is x86-64-v1.
&slsa; 16 supports AMD and Intel 64-bit architectures (x86-64-v2, preparing for x86-64-v3), 64-bit ARM (ARMv8.0-A), IBM Power Systems Little Endian (POWER9), and 64-bit IBM Z

&slsa; 16 supports AMD and Intel 64-bit architectures (x86-64-v2, preparing to run x86-64-v3), the 64-bit ARM architecture (ARMv8.0-A), &ibm; &power; Systems Little Endian (POWER9), and 64-bit IBM Z (z14).
&slsa; 15 utilizes Service Packs (SPs) for annual updates, such as SP1, SP2, SP3, SP4, SP5, SP6, and SP7, which is the last SP released for &slsa; 15.

SLE 16 introduces a new naming schema for versions, using minor releases like 16.0, 16.1, instead of SPs. Releases are scheduled annualy and always in November. The initial release, 16.0, is planned for November 2025.

&sls; 15 has general support for 1.5 years per Service Pack (with exceptions) and offers various extended support options like LTSS (Long Term Service Pack Support) and ESPOS (Extended Service Pack Overlap Support). Total support for SLE 15 covers up to 13 years (10 years general support + 3 years LTSS). &slsa; 15 SP7 general support is until 2031-07-31, with LTSS until 2034-07-31 and LTSS Core until 2037-12-31. &sles4sap; 15 SPs have a total support of 4.5 years.

&slsa; 16 is ready for the future beyond 2038. General Support is expected to end in November 2035, with LTSS and Extreme LTSS beyond 2040. &sles4sap; 16 has general support for 1.5 years plus 3 years extended support.
In &slsa; 15 and earlier used &yast; for installation, configuration, and systems management. Unattended and scripted installation was performed by &ay;.
In &slsa; 16, systems management sees significant changes:

Installation (including unattended) transitions to &agama;. &agama; is a new installer with a web-based frontend, command-line interface, and API for integration. It focuses on the installation in favor of software configuration management (SCM) tools. Agama supports repeated config import.
Configuration management uses &salt; and &ansible; via &smlm;. This supports customers with ready-to-run automation.
Remote management is handled by &cockpit;, a web-based frontend for 1:1 management.

These changes in &slsa; 16 aim to provide better integration with &salt; and &ansible;, allow remote installation via a web browser, and offer different interfaces (web, CLI, HTTP API) for controlling the process.
&slsa; 15 uses &aa; by default. &selnx; is shipped without policies.

&slsa; 16 ships &selnx; with policies for over 400 modules by default, confining almost the whole system. Parts of the system can run unconfined if desired. &sles4sap; 16 has improved workload isolation with &selnx;, providing isolation for data and data flows, and for containers.
&slsa; 15 used wicked and &nm;.
&slsa; 16 focuses on a single stack using &nm;.

&slsa; 15 offered ready-to-run images for VM, public cloud, and manual deployment (&yast;, &ay;). It used a special installation environment with linuxrc-driven configuration. &ay; profile import was a one-off task only.

&slsa; 16 uses ready-to-run images for VM, public cloud, and manual/automated deployment with &agama;. The &agama; installer is accessible via web-interface, command line, or HTTP API. &agama; allows repeated config import. It uses a standard live medium with dracut, &systemd;, and NetworkManager. There is a backward-compatibility layer with selected linuxrc options.
&slsa; 15 used &systemd; with compatibility for SysV init scripts.
&slsa; 16 uses &systemd; with native units. Transition from SysV init is finished.
In &slsa; 15, the default OS configuration was primarily in /etc.

In &slsa; 16, defaults are in /usr and /etc for customization. This separation of vendor-provided defaults and administrator customization allows easier updates and — optionally — write-only /usr file system.
&slsa; 15 used &gnome; as the default desktop environment. &sled; and &slewe; shared desktop productivity tools.
&slsa; 16 uses a minimal &gnome; desktop. This helps minimize the security surface. &sled; is not planned for 16.0.

section.title: Removed Technology
section.para: &slsa; 16 removes certain technologies to reduce the OS footprint and the security attack vector:

listitem.para: NIS is no longer used; customers can choose LDAP instead.
The ISC DHCP server was removed in favor of the more modern Kea DHCP.
32-bit application support is removed, although the Linux kernel can still enable 32-bit system calls with a boot time option.
SysV init scripts are removed; use native &systemd; units instead.
wicked is removed in favor of &nm;.
